"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/558874f9636872695e0001b0#post_558874f9636872695e0001b0

That's bound to happen as technology advances, however, the human body will still need traditional medicine lest people have artificial blood which no matter how far society advances will always have that clutch of "Consumed by tech". Yes, some cybernetics augmentations will become part, heck some already are, in terms of limbs (an eye, a leg, another organ.).

There's never going to be a entirely cybernetic because the line between organic brain processes and artificial simply can't co-exist. Emotions are chemical reactions and you can make the argument they are simulations and really something unique to animals or man and they can be recreated via a computer but, what would you rather have? Someone who says "I like you" and is just saying it because they are programmed to say it or someone who you know is honest in that regard.

There's many opinions in this matter and everyone will say something different based on their emotional status, current life style, etc. So it's never going to go away and it's going to be a constant no matter how advanced society grows. There's always going to be the need of keeping the brain as less tech upgraded as you can. Some will take it to extreme measures I'm not saying they won't.

But I don't see that singularity of man and machine becoming a single entity.

topics.body:
If humans do become primarily mechanical it would probably be because of financial pressure.

Let's add up all the stuff:
Eating, showering, water, AC/Heater to keep you comfortable, water heating, medical bills, insurance, dentist, glasses, constantly having to wash clothing cause of your sweat, constantly having to buy new clothing, winter jackets, light bulbs too see.

Most of your income is already eaten up before you can even spend it.  When we do get cheap mechanical parts for humans chances are insurance companies would pressure a lot of people to get them by offering less and less treatment for organic body parts and more and more coverage for mechanical.

My guess in a nutshell:
"Hello Dave; this is your insurance company.  I regret to inform you that we no longer cover heart transplants; if you want a mechanical heart we cover that"
"Hello Dave; this is your insurance company.  I regret to inform you that we no longer cover glasses; if you want artificial eyes we cover that"
"Hello Dave; this is your insurance company.  I'm sorry Dave.  I can't let you do that; we no longer cover blood transfusions.  If you want artificial blood we cover that"

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/558877006368727aee000339#post_558877006368727aee000339
It's theoretically possible to transfer a consciousness to another body; it's just *WAY* out of our current level of technology.  It won't be possible technologically for another 40 to 50 years.

You know the bottle and the egg experiment to get it in the bottle?  Metaphorically it's similar concept.  You wouldn't be able to shove it into the new body, nor would you be able to copy it, etc but rather essentially hook up the mind with it's new body and essentially make it to where the computer brain takes higher priority and has higher performance thus pressuring the mind to get vacuumed into the new body.

I'm obviously drastically simplifying here, but it's the best summary I can think of to get the idea across.  It's not going to be here for decades, but it's not impossible. . . HOWEVER considering how jarring such a experience would be I would have to drastically suggest that when it does become possible for people to not start body hoping as a hobby.  Streaming a entire consciousness would probably be a extremely jarring experience and if a person did it too often that might cause severe mental problems.  It would probably develop into a new mental illness of people cause chances are some people wouldn't listen and thus well you can probably imagine the damage constantly hoping bodies would do.

Tl:dr; it's not impossible; it's just incredibly complicated and when we eventually do develop the technology for the love of god listen to your doctor and don't do body hopping as a hobby.

Tl:dr of Tl:dr; if people start viewing that as like getting a new Ipod then that would be asking for trouble.  Transferring a consciousness would be a long term commitment not a fashion fad.
